------=_NextPart_000_00C5_01C797D3.28BB84E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Ken and Petar,
 
If I understand correctly what you are trying to accomplish, you might want
to look a force-directed graph placement algorithm for node placement given
connection nodes. Examples are Fruchterman-Reingold, Eades, Kamada-Kawai,
Hadany-Harel.  Personally, I use Gajer-Kobourov GRIP (Graph dRawing with
Intelligent Placement).  There have been great strides in reducing the time
complexity in these algorithms, and these may be expanded (with little
adaptation) to n-dimensional cubes (and with a little more effort separable
n-dim Hilbert spaces, or Riemann spaces).
 
Genome graphs may be then be presented in a GUI in OpenGL or DirectX.  The
actual arithmetic computations for simulations can also be off-loaded to the
GPU (as I have alluded to earlier).
 
A simple virtual quaternion trackball may be used to manipulate the view.
 
Ken
 
 


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Kenneth Stanley
Sent: Wednesday, May 16, 2007 3:30 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Substrate Configuration GUI



Peter, that's true, it could potentially support general placement 
schemes that are independent of resolution/density. If you do 
implement any such GUI please share it with the group since it will 
be quit interesting!

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com,
"petar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi, Ken. 
> 
> This is a good idea and I'll try to implement one. It should be 
easy, 
> like writing a paint program. :)
> Something came to my mind right now. Such a GUI should support 
general 
> node placement concepts too (like arranging nodes in a circle or a 
> matrix), so the same substrate file can be reused in multiple node 
> densities. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Kenneth
Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > I know this is going to happen sooner or later, but Thomas's 
recent 
> > question brought it to mind. It will be really interesting 
someday 
> to 
> > be able to set up substrates with a GUI, so you can intuitively 
> specify 
> > how inputs/outputs/hidden nodes are configured and run a range 
of 
> > experiments quickly. There are many ways that such an app could 
be 
> set 
> > up but however it works it would certainly be fun to play with 
in 
> > conjunction with a HyperNEAT system.
> > 
> > ken
> >
>
